title: Crowded LLM Market Demands Clear Differentiation
content:
**The Crowded Space (Refresher):** Many of you have used chatGPT, which
is one the most popular Large Language Models. HuggingFace.com, the
marketplace for chatGPT and other LLMs hosts hundreds of thousands of
such models. Including Small and Medium models, the site hosts over 1.5M
models. Here are some popular LLMs:

Following OpenAI ChatGPT release in late 2020, Llama (by Meta in Feb
'23), Claude (by Anthropic in Mar '23), Bard which got rebranded as
Gemini (by Google in Mar '23), Perplexity (by Perplexity AI in Oct '23),
Grok (by Musk in Nov '23) and DeepSeek the newest, cheapest and latest
Chinese entrant in Jan '25.

**Model Progression:** The models have progressed to build
multi-modality to input text, voice, images and to generate text, voice,
images, and videos in response. Remember the two dimensions here of the
models: multi-modality and the generative nature of these models making
them very powerful over time.

-   The operator mode of the LLMs can execute task like grocery ordering
    > or travel booking autonomously by handing complex multistep
    > processes without any human intervention

-   The operator mode can also generate powerful graphical user
    > interfaces and integration of third-party tools like Google
    > Workspace, Slack or Microsoft Office

-   In addition to the operator mode, the models have also developed
    > reasoning abilities to decompose a problem into multiple steps
    > with chain of thoughts or tree of thoughts logic. With this
    > approach a problem is solved with a little more time in the play
    > however it has a more realistic and methodical approach in solving
    > the problem. This behavior provides a lot more meaningful
    > responses in solving problems related to healthcare, education and
    > technical support interactions

-   The latest capability introduced in chatGPT is to generate powerful
    > visuals with far more accurate textual elements and real life look
    > and feel in the images

So, why would I share this refresher? One element is to understand the
comprehension and the competition in the space and the other is to
simplify integration of these models in real-life scenarios.

**Orchestration:**

-   Imagine as a doctor, if you would like to leverage your specific
    > patient's history, or anonymously leveraging all your patients'
    > interactions and combining them with powerful knowledge from
    > research books. You can selectively generative capabilities of
    > LLMs to leverage this knowledge and get many more perspectives
    > invisible to the human eye/brain

-   In other examples, marketer can build the same leverage with a
    > campaign, repository of all campaigns or industry knowledge to
    > generate more intelligence leveraging LLMs

-   Same theory applies to Software Developer's knowledgebase, a Tutor
    > and her notes, a Storyteller and her stories, and many more use
    > cases

The **Model Context Protocol** (MCP) is an open standard introduced by
Anthropic in November 2024 to enable seamless integration between AI
systems and external tools or data sources. MCP (no males involved
here - just the model) eliminates the need for custom integrations by
providing a universal framework, allowing large language models (LLMs)
to securely access real-time context and interact with diverse systems
like databases, APIs, and content repositories as mentioned in the
examples above.

Here is the depiction of such a process where you right hand side could
be any form of knowledge and tools that can feed that knowledge into the
LLMs

![](media/image6.png){width="6.5in" height="4.333333333333333in"}

**The Future:** This landscape is getting far more comprehensive and
competitive. Not many of the LLM companies are making proportionate
revenue for the cost of infrastructure in deploying these models. The
hope for the future still remains bullish and perhaps AGI (Artificial
General Intelligence) will change the game.

**What is in it for me?** In discussing these opportunities, I come
across a handful of naysayers. A technology leader refuses to use these
capabilities as she wants her employees to understand the underlying
layers of programming before the employees can use these answer sheets
or co-pilot coders.

It took me back to my engineering years and possibly some of you can
relate to the same. High-schools are teaching a lot of programming
languages and excel workings that we (and many of you) learnt late in
your learning cycle.

Students and Employees need to learn both methodical workings to know
what is under the hood and also exploit tools in a far more proportion
that is going to propel the journey. A reminder once again, your job or
profession will not be replaced by a machine but it is certainly
vulnerable to the ones that know how to use AI in the same context. So,
are you ready?

title: Western TV Ads Reveal Consumer Anxieties
content:
Television sets at most of the hotels in California are not upgraded to
the smart ones yet, which gave me some exposure to local TV channels in
the recent weeks. Compared to the Eastern hemisphere, the West still
follows a lot of traditional television, especially the news channels.
Theme of the advertisements on the channels were three fold, largely
speaking.

-   Pharmaceutical/Medicinal advertisements for skin diseases, weight
    > management, depression and diabetes are the ones that I can
    > remember

-   There were quite a few advertisements from life, health and property
    > insurance companies

-   Lastly, all the channels consistently showed legal/law firms that
    > would fight for you, mostly to make money from accidents based
    > lawsuits

All the pharma advertisements had fast voiceover of disclaimers to
defend from any future lawsuits. Insurance companies promoted defense
from life and health events. Law firms showed you all possible ways how
accident victims could make money from so-called offenders.

In a good way, I know of two family friends who did not file a lawsuit
for a handful of accidents they met with and let go of the individuals
that erred. So, why this preface?

I want to write about two things based on this narrative: Assurance from
Insurance and secondly about how we should make decisions.

**Assurance from Insurance:** Common forms of insurance include health
coverage, life insurance policies, automobiles and travel insurances.
Most employers provide coverage for health and life insurances.
Automobile insurance is somewhat mandatory across the developed world.
We get a sense of assurance from insurances for personal and family's
well being to defend from untimely events in life.

Working (or not working) for an employer, fighting for a promotion in a
given job, to relocate for work, and to make a significant shift in your
professional life involve a certain amount of risk taking, as we
constantly seek assurances. These risk avoiding behaviors reflect on the
need for insurance to make decisions. Most always we make decisions in
favor of materialistic outcomes and as such there is nothing wrong with
it.

At this point, let's think about our cognitive (in)abilities that lead
us to making certain choices.

**Decision Making:** We often have these deja vu moments and possible
regrets regarding new products (it was my idea), investments (I knew
this company isn't going to do well), relationships (I knew from the
beginning they were not meant for each other) and a long list of things.

We come across a lot of information and decision crossroads to pick an
option from many. We decide for

-   Academic path to follow (specific stream and levels to get the
    > Master's or Doctorate)

-   Mode of employment and the associated employer(s)

-   Rent or Buy a property

-   Choosing a life partner

-   Investments we make and a lot more

Here is a perspective to not have a long list of regrettable things. I
was advising a founder CTO last week regarding how to introduce AI in
their product and business operations. The leader of this company (the
CEO) is in hyper growth mode primarily focusing on selling their high in
demand product to new customers. Being a start-up there is not much
appetite to make huge investments for introducing AI/LLM capabilities.

I suggested that the CTO employ a simple model with her leadership team
(the details in the parenthesis which is specific guidance from me to
her and may be slightly technical in nature so ignore them based on your
readership):

-   **Build a model that shows options or choices** (4 Choices: Radical
    > or Incremental introduction of AI in operational and product
    > capabilities in this instance)

-   **Make a recommendation** (Recommending a feature set introduction
    > that leveraged AI/LLM, specifically Agentic RAG, capability in one
    > of their product lines and introducing AI enablement in the
    > operational world, in this instance - this would give a jump
    > start)

-   **Recommend investments and advantages from making this choice**
    > (Upkeep within the industry, Competitive landscape and definitive
    > product advantages in this instance)

-   **Outcomes from not making this choice** (dilution in competitive
    > rigor, in this instance)

-   **Risks associated** (A slightly longer product cycle to begin with,
    > in this instance)

If at first this model or the approach is rejected, go back in 45 days
clearly indicating what we lost from inaction. The rationale for
recommendations can include some or all of the following in the
descending order of priority: What we do will positively disrupt our
world, increase revenue/profitability, save resources (money, headcount,
and time), and significantly enhance life experiences.

In utilizing this model, don't apply this to make small decisions.
Imagine if you had such a comprehensive workflow to decide on which
flavor of ice cream to eat.

Some more 'To Dos' and 'Don\'ts'

**Do**

-   Be cognitively super-aware of size and impact of the decisions

-   Read and research similar historical data points

-   Predict what the future holds for the world around us

-   Make sure the time is right and remember it is never too late

-   Ensure your basics are protected (Capital protection, Family
    > wellbeing etc.)

-   Have a sense of gratitude towards what you already have accomplished

**Do not**

-   Follow the crowd

-   Let someone decide for you

-   Do not sweat on small decisions - eat your ice cream and make sure
    > to burn it down

-   Accept your surrounding and live with mediocrity

-   buy Insurance for everything at the cost of not experimenting

There is a lot more however I am breaking here to grab my cappuccino,
let's add cocoa powder as well.

**Now the Tariff Wars**

-   To manage ever increasing debt (\$38T), headwinds from inflation,
    > possibly to bring production domestically and to boost the

    > tariffs on the supplying world, especially the likes of China or

    > manufacturers will simply pass on the cost to the consumers

    > starting with power (energy) demands, infrastructure, attached
    > technology in manufacturing, associated labor and most importantly
    > the will power of the population to do these high intensity jobs.
    > This will not happen overnight and will take a long term of 5 to
    > 10 years, if at all

-   Outsourcing and offshoring have evolved for a reason to provide the
    > economy of scale. Just look at how the disproportionately high
    > populations in India and China have enabled this for years

-   In this trade war, there will be marginal winners and losers with
    > zero net gains

-   Nothing seemingly will make any of the nations more productive right
    > away and additionally causing a lot of near and mid term
    > derailments

-   Somewhere to manage the manufacturing price and the process, the
    > manufacturing countries will have to introduce substandard
    > mechanics which will negatively impacting their population and the
    > environment

-   If the manufacturing did move to the US in some cases, the cost of
    > production will still be high or even higher. This will force some
    > form of domestic subsidies to increase affordability of expensive
    > goods

Fortunately there are some early signs of negotiations and
considerations. Many considerations are required beyond economic growth.
Clear skies and clean air in some geographies will not prevent natural
calamities around the planet.

The planet does not benefit from the big becoming bigger. It does not
benefit from the increased gap between number 1 and number 2, number 2
and number 3. Citizens of the world need to survive from wars and
pandemics. We do not need this price (tariff) war right now on top of
everything.

title: AI Conflicts With Human Creative Touch
content:
**Making peace with AI:[C]{.underline}onflicts and Human Touch:**

Before I get into the depth of this topic, there is a correlation which
some have laughed about: The over-referenced
**[C]{.underline}**haracterization of powerful words in my life that
begin with a "**C**".

My first strategic technology framework from 2010 was based on 4 themes:
**[C]{.underline}**loud, **[C]{.underline}**onsolidation,
**[C]{.underline}**ompliance and **[C]{.underline}**ost. The Management
workshop that I **[C]{.underline}**onceived as "Leadership Laboratory"
is based on 4 **[C]{.underline}**s: **[C]{.underline}**ustomers,
**[C]{.underline}**ommunication, **[C]{.underline}**ognizance and
**[C]{.underline}**harisma. A few more "**[C]{.underline}**s" to add
today.

**Technology: [C]{.underline}onflict of [C]{.underline}reativity vs.
[C]{.underline}ementation/[C]{.underline}omfort:** I saw a podcast
yesterday where a presenter was sharing concerns about how AI will
possibly **[C]{.underline}**ement the **[C]{.underline}**reativity of
the Human Mind. In another incident, a technology leader was hesitant to
introduce 'AI' tools in his company with the fear that his employees
would not understand the foundational concepts of technology due to 'AI'
driven automation. This fear exists with parents whose children are
leveraging AI to do homework, all kinds of artists who feel their art
will not be appreciated due to AI-generated art, and more. This
**[C]{.underline}**onflict---technology and AI
**[C]{.underline}**ementing processes and killing creativity---has
induced a lot of reluctance and fear in humans. There is also a fear
that AI will make humans more **[C]{.underline}**omfortable and lonely
as a result. Fear arising from excessive use of (Ro)bots in our lives
leading to **[C]{.underline}**omfort in loneliness.

**Distinguishing Internet, [C]{.underline}loud and AI:** They certainly
evolved in the order of their mention. We have been using the internet
from the early 1990s to search and to access a lot of information from
the WWW (World Wide Web). Similarly the **[C]{.underline}**loud became
popular from 2008 onwards. A simple example of **[C]{.underline}**loud
is in accessing your emails. You may not have been a creator in the
cloud era, however all of us are definite consumers of the cloud.

AI is different. Imagine these three vectors: Individualism,
Industrialism and Information Technology stack.

-   As an Individual AI is far more accessible for both creation and
    > consumption. You can become far more productive and competitive as
    > an AI user in your personal capacity

-   Industrial growth will accelerate from AI: Automobile, Agriculture,
    > Manufacturing, Healthcare and all you can name. Combination of
    > Data, Robotics, AI and other technologies will provide hyper
    > acceleration in social and economic reforms built in these
    > industries

-   Leveraging AI in the Information Technology stack to build
    > disruptive applications is inevitable

This narrative necessitates confrontation with AI, and in the absence of
that, you will lose your edge as an individual, industrialist or
technologist without this embracement.

**Are you [C]{.underline}onflicted with this AI intimidation?**

If yes then read on. If not then ask why not? Dealing with any conflict
needs dissection.

-   Firstly, build **[C]{.underline}**ourage to define your conflict.
    > Know what has led you to avoid this, both as acknowledgement and
    > awareness

-   Second phase is to build **[C]{.underline}**uriosity after
    > **[C]{.underline}**ourageously **[C]{.underline}**onfronting. Ask
    > questions to know why the conflict began in the first place. What
    > stopped you from addressing this so far? If you personally do not
    > have this conflict, and you are courageous enough, then determine
    > how you will create **[C]{.underline}**uriosity for others to
    > embrace AI

-   Lastly, build **[C]{.underline}**larity for action. What are the
    > next steps? What tools do I employ and how will I bring awareness,
    > education and utilization in perspective? Are you building
    > awareness of tools outside of your natural choices? ChatGPT is
    > just the beginning of this journey. Feel free to write to me if
    > you need help with starting points. Even if I may not know
    > personally, I will have enough resources to guide us

This model of **[C]{.underline}**ourage, **[C]{.underline}**uriosity and
**[C]{.underline}**larity can be used with any kind of organizational,
interpersonal, or even personal **[C]{.underline}**onflicts.

title: AI in Action or Just Inaction
content:
This write-up though delayed is an instigator and a bit longer. It is a
process to take a pause from the ordinary and see how you will change a
few ways of working with AI or if you are a newbie to AI then how this
can all start in a very refreshing way.

**AI: 'in Action' or 'Inaction':** Following my rant on AI conflicts and
human touch last week, here is some more. Imagine if AI can become
powerful to understand your context, your intent and very particularly
the tone of your voice. How can you better collaborate with AI? This is
with an assurance that it will not kill your creativity, unlike the
obvious fears, but make you more creative.

If you are a non-technical professional and want to collaborate better
with Generative AI (ChatGPT and her cousins) then this is for you. By
the way, we now give this recognition to chatGPT so she can now have
identity (She/Her) on her LinkedIn account. If you are a technical
professional then you can use this point of view for yourself and/or to
inspire other non-technical associates, professionals or not. This
process can dramatically augment and amplify your creativity.

-   Instead of asking direct questions to LLMs, we should ask LLMs first
    > to say, 'What is the best way for me to ask this question to AI
    > for it to answer it well?' You see the point and if you do not
    > read this again

-   With this you can now ask 'AI to use AI' as opposed to how we could
    > not use Excel to use Excel, which would have sounded oxymoronic in
    > the years

-   Ask AI (ChatGPT or any of her cousin) to find how I can best
    > leverage AI: Ask AI to ask you enough questions till it
    > understands your responsibilities, workflows, and KPIs (Key
    > Performance Indicators)

-   After she has learnt about you, now ask her to make two obvious and
    > two not-so obvious recommendations

-   Given the neuronic being of LLMs/AI, it will continuously assess her
    > own work. If you watch the blog below you will see a beauty in an
    > example where a non-technical professional was able to build a
    > very highly effective tool using AI, for many many professionals

-   Many of us are not able to fully utilize AI's true potential (90% of
    > us to be specific)

-   Outperformers treat AI like a teammate compared to a tool. As a
    > teammate, when you get mediocre performance you give him/her the
    > feedback - why would you not do the same with AI. Give feedback,
    > coach AI, and improvise her context in your engagement

-   In an example in the same podcast here, you will see how you can use
    > AI to simulate an individual who you might be having a
    > confrontational conversation with

-   Without the interactive and iterative process with AI/LLMs, you will
    > fixate on the first response as an obvious solution. I am sure
    > there is a lot more however here is the link to the podcast

    > indirectly

    > a non-professional orientation

    > the process and build inference in your personal technical or
    > non-technical capacity

**Automating the Thoughts Engine with Generative AI:** As you all know,
I write every week and have a linear document that tracks my 'Sunday
Thoughts' which are separated by date of authoring. I have a
distribution list of people that I send these thoughts to by email.

I decided to improvise the initially created 'Sunday Thoughts' portal
using AI tools to accelerate and simplify the distribution process. In
addition, preceding the distribution a lot goes in organizing the
content intricately, again using AI tools. Here are some more details on
how the AI engine helps me to do my job. Some parts are repeated here
from my past update however without them it will not give a holistic
view of the process

**Content Organization**

![](media/image18.png){width="5.463542213473316in"
height="3.642361111111111in"}

-   I created an API (Application Programming Interface - an automated
    > way to summon chatGPT from my software code) to access ChatGPT in
    > its operator mode

-   I asked chatGPT to write a python script (python is a popular
    > programming/scripting language) by first taking the large
    > monolithic file of 100+ articles and dividing it into individual
    > pdf files, using author date as a delimiter. 30 seconds later I
    > had the individual pdf files

-   I created a repository on Supabase/Postgres database portal (similar
    > to Google drive but with specialization for accessing data in a
    > specific format) to store my data and the content files (Images,
    > Writeups, and more)

-   Database stores information of my subscribers with basic user
    > profile and a separate table (just like an excel sheet) for my
    > write ups to track article title, creation date, document name,
    > image file for the article, article pdf file name, formatted write
    > up for web rendering, category of the writeup as mentioned in the
    > four categories (Technology/AI, Macroeconomics, Thought Leadership
    > and Geopolitics), determining if the content is dated in terms of
    > time relevance or ageless and lastly tracking comments of my
    > readers

-   I created another file store on Supabase to save images for the
    > write ups, pdf file of the writeups, and audio version of the AI
    > generated podcast

-   I asked chatGPT to write another python script to take each of the

    -   Give an AI generated title for the document

    -   Identify category combination based on the content in the
        > writeup

    -   Asked chatGPT to generate an image that can best represent this
        > article

    -   Save the created date

    -   Take all the generated and known data for each of the files
        > subsequently to create an entry in my database to use it for
        > my distribution portal

**Content Distribution**

![](media/image17.png){width="6.5in" height="2.6944444444444446in"}

-   This part is for my portal for content distribution. I used Vercel
    > to host my portal site

-   I used an image from my imagination to ask Vercel to give me basic

-   I used Cursor.ai to develop the website using Next.js and React.js

    -   React.js is a library for building user interfaces, mainly

    -   Next.js is a framework built on React that adds server-side

    -   In short: React builds components; Next.js builds entire web

title: Technology Concentrates Wealth in Few Hands
content:
**Technological Explosion and its impact on Wealth: Growth, Disparity
and Redistribution**

"Unicorn" is a privately held company with a valuation of \$1B+ and
"Decacorn" is similarly valued at \$10B+. This is a prediction that,
very soon, we will likely have Unicorns run by a single individual.
Let's say that, at least in today's times, I have seen half a dozen
founders running enterprises valued over \$1B+. Yes, just 6 employees in
the company.

Cutting-edge technology has empowered a selective, small group of people
to generate enormous amounts of wealth or valuation. This has, and will
continue to, introduce greater disparities in the wealth distribution.
Here is a quick view of the global wealth and GDP evolution across the
past four Industrial Revolutions.

I.  Invention of the Steam Engine enabled a lot of factories and
    > automation in the second half of the 18th century and first half
    > of the 19th. The global GDP was tracked at roughly \$500B at that
    > point in time. 90% of the national wealth was held by 10% of the
    > British population, with Britain being at the forefront of the
    > growth curve

II. Electrification, Railroads and more led to the second revolution in
    > the late second half of the 19th century. The global GDP was
    > tracked at \$2.7T at that point in time, roughly 5.5 times that of
    > the first revolution. The top 2% of the nation owned 50% of the
    > national wealth in the United States, as it started to dominate
    > the world order

III. The Tech boom in the second half of the 20th century provided a
     > much larger growth narrative. The US' dominance continued in the
     > 3rd Industrial Revolution as the global GDP grew 13x over 100
     > years from \$2.7T to \$41T

IV. In the 4th revolution, technology continues to dominate, and the
    > global GDP grew to \$110T+ as projected for this year. The world
    > order remains somewhat challenged - the US still leads the pack
    > however, the future will most likely have the world order
    > leadership somewhat divided

**Democracy and Communism:**

In a nutshell, Democracy is a political system, and Communism is built
around economic and political ideologies. Here are some key differences
between the two:

1.  In a democracy, multiple political parties compete, compared to a
    > single party communist ruling

2.  Democratic nations have largely capitalistic approach, and Communism
    > is built around collective or state based ownership, largely
    > controlled by few individuals over a long span of time

3.  Communism aims to create a classless society and largely suppresses
    > freedom (speech) to retain the state's ideology

4.  You can compare democratic nations like the US, India, Japan and
    > Germany to countries based on Communist ideologies like North
    > Korea, Cuba, Russia and China

Now, imagine a triangle with Government as one vertex, Industries as the
second and People as the third. Wealth is largely generated through
industrial revolutions, which is accrued and consumed by people, and
somehow regularized by the Government through policies and taxes. Each
vertex helps maintain balance in this triangle by pulling or pushing to
make an ideal equilateral triangle. However, between the industries,
individuals, and geographies, the representations of these triangles can
often become scalene.

Democratic nations are largely capitalist in nature. Sometimes,
Communist countries try to simulate 'Capitalist' behaviors to create a
people and industry led growth mindset. This is actually a dangerous
approach. Look at what happened to Alibaba and Jack Ma following their
respective growth in PRC (People's Republic of China).

**Socialism: Collective ownership leading to equality, welfare and
regulated markets**

By definition, socialism can exist in both Democratic and Communist
nations. They use policies to bring parity in well-being through
progressive taxation, universal healthcare, education and pensions.

**How should the employment and wealth imbalance from AI disruption be
managed? Is UBI (Universal Basic Income) the answer?**

Just go back to the triangle of Industries, People and the Government.
When we have excessive wealth and power imbalances, the world will
become more aggressive and revolutionary.

To prevent that, there should/will be governmental intervention.
Although desirable, 'Universal Basic Income' is a very hard state to
achieve. This is why?

-   "Universal" applies to all humans, and given the unique powers,
    > resources, and technological advances of each of the countries, we
    > will continue to live in the imbalances

-   People have wealth inherited and generated over centuries and
    > decades. This cannot be disrupted

-   Giving free money has never been a good sign. In the COVID years, a
    > lot of the stimulus funding was abused for luxuries or substances

This only means that the third vertex of the triangle, in the form of
government, will have to create an amenable social structure through
education, healthcare, subsidies and taxation. The disruption from the
new age tech revolution is inevitable, and only time will determine the
level of impact it will create in inequitable wealth distribution.
Hopefully, common sense will prevail as it has for the centuries.

title: Gut Feelings Drive Most Decisions Actually

relevance.Self_Awareness: How intuition and gut feelings drive most decision-making

content:
"Gut feelings" are instincts arising from the brain-gut connection. Gut
microbiome influences our emotions and decisions, triggering
subconscious brain responses, mostly irrational. Gut itself is as big as
the brain of a dog or a cat and hosts 500 million neurons which send
signals to the brain.

**So, why talk about the Gut Feelings to start with?**

Firstly, to understand what we mean by gut feelings, and secondly to
build awareness in order to manage our anxiety from the subconsciousness
that gut feelings create. Most mental uncertainties are from the fear
that originates from anxieties, largely initiated by the gut. In
reality, when we are in fear, we tend to give up what we really want.
What do we give up and what are some of the actions attached to not
giving up? This writeup was inspired by this short ted talk so here is
the quick reference for credit.

[[https://youtu.be/bRtBHF-WPpM?si=dZHXDMpdaZhr9-mp]{.underline}](https://youtu.be/bRtBHF-WPpM?si=dZHXDMpdaZhr9-mp)

**Unfolding the Process of Wants**

We often find ourselves in a wrong job, uncertain relationships, and
avoidance of medical diagnosis, all of which result in a prolonged
procrastination. Something that holds us captive in the avoidance mode.

Of all the things that I could gather from the podcast, doing a
'Self-Audit' stayed with me the strongest.

**What does the audit entail**? Many dimensions - mental state, health,
relationships, materialistic expectations, my excuses and a long list of
things.

We often tend to use excuses to defend our avoidance. Excuses of impact
on children from a toxic marriage, excuses for financial needs to be
fulfilled while working for an incompetent leader and I am sure you have
your reasons for specific avoidances in your pocket. The underlying
thought of, 'I am in the wrong place', does not go away.

**How do you conduct a self-audit?**

1.  In the list of your wants (what do I want part), identify the pivot
    > of the decision - decision of your career, a given job,
    > relationship, or health perspectives, whatever it might be?

2.  Do an exercise just like you would in a fish bone analysis. If you
    > are unfamiliar with a fish bone map then just look it up or
    > perhaps I can write about it in future

3.  As you identify dependencies around your want, determine if these
    > dependencies are not your additional wants as well. Sometimes
    > working for an incompetent leader or being in a toxic relationship
    > for non-negotiable monetary expectations, play a tug of war

4.  In the above parallel wants or needs scenario, appreciate that
    > implicit material needs might be a bigger aspect that you may have
    > been oblivious to

5.  As you do the exercise, your mind expands or contracts with choices,
    > you sense fear or joy with choices, you find excitement or dread
    > with choices and some choices still keep you suffocated. Observe
    > the impact on your mental state from these audit talks

6.  Involve your gut again with the audit and ask, 'Am I really in that
    > bad a place?'

7.  A lot must be done with self before you seek help - do a deep
    > assessment in isolation with that said

8.  You can feed all these aspects into an LLM and ask questions. You
    > will amazed with the mirror you see here however ultimately you
    > are the one who should decide what you want

9.  In lieu of an LLM or in addition, validating with your mentor helps
    > as well. If you have a mentor go to him/her and if not find a
    > mentor

As you conduct the audit, keep in mind that you should ask a lot of
questions, be honest to yourself, seek help and actively appreciate
possible outcomes of action or inaction for what you want in life. This
is painful however it will also provide you a launching pad for a
quantum leap.

Lastly, ensure that the audit does not get you into daily
analysis-paralysis syndrome. Engage with the outcomes of the audit and
cool down until the next audit, which cannot happen until another
significant milestone in your life.

title: High Stakes Presentations Demand Thoughtful Preparation

relevance.Communication: Preparing for high-stakes presentations to executives

content:
I was speaking at one of our company events and during the Q&A session
somebody asked me a specific question on the future with AI. My
immediate response was that I would have paid him a handsome amount to
ask the question, not getting into the specificity of the questions for
today's topic. I was excited as I had conspired some questions that were
off-topic.

One of the hardest things is in prepping for a big presentation to the
executives or for a talk to a large group. "Watch your thoughts, they
become words; watch your words, they become actions" and simply to put
in action instead of just watching, conspiring with these can actually
help you accelerate.

**Conspiring in the "Magical Kingdom" of Mind**

Breadth and Depth in knowledge are equally important. However, before
big events like above, you will need to conspire deeply in parts.

**The Thinking/Applying Part**

-   **Magic of 'Framework' thinking:** First principles always work the
    > best. Identify the fundamental elements of a topic at hand, all
    > the parts. For example, to present an effective marketing
    > campaign, think about the product, the customer, the value
    > proposition as it would appeal to her, and most importantly the
    > interdependence of each part on the other as it would stitch up
    > the story. If you have an existing template that worked in the
    > past deconstruct it and then reconstruct with your applied
    > thinking, while conspiring with the current situation

-   Secondly, also think of an inversion mindset based on what you want
    > to avoid. What do they not want to hear and what will not give you
    > the sense of immense satisfaction in the post-presentation review.
    > As an example, you know the job title you aspire for, number of
    > followers you are looking for on social media, the compensation
    > you want, the industry and the kind of employer you want to work
    > for, the people that you want to associate with: use all these
    > elements to determine what you do not want to see happen

-   Do not use the baseline pre-existing model as-is, do not follow the
    > guidance blindly, think independently and think all the time, of
    > course not getting into a depressive state but to remain ecstatic
    > about the opportunity. Do not worry about 'what if it fails' like
    > negativity

**Penning it down**

At this stage, you will dictate your mind on a piece of paper, or a
digital document.

Writing helps you to organize your thoughts, it is also like reading
your material twenty times, and to unmuddle the mind. Once you start
writing it will help you to standardize, deduplicate, organize and most
importantly discard the material you do not find relevant. Just to write
these thoughts, I plug all my research material and then start
discarding elements that are relatively duplicative or irrelevant as I
progress through the page(s).

**Rehearsing and Presenting the Narrative**

A little bit on how you can build confidence with your articulation. In
one of the podcasts I heard this weekend it was said: Those who can
articulate are dangerous people, positively speaking. Our body joints
articulate and similarly if you can get your tongue to do the dance then
your magic will influence the others:

-   Many are lucky in their upbringing. My father was a school teacher
    > and taught English language and Mathematics. He taught us grammar
    > mathematically and he had many impromptu conversations and quizzes
    > for us. This is the first time I have ever mentioned him in my
    > writings. We were brought up in a very modest setup although
    > fortunate enough to have these intellectually enriching
    > conversations at dinner time or otherwise

-   Most academia does not provide any formal structure on articulation.
    > This will need a continuous personal investment and the earlier
    > you can make it happen, the better it is

-   In order to practice, speak in front of a mirror and record on your
    > phone. You should dry run with those who can observe and help
    > control your body language, observe the fillers and the general
    > flow that will help you grab your audience's attention. Get into
    > intelligent debates on the topic with your colleagues and friends

-   When practicing remember that this has to be an intense integration
    > of language and articulation. It will help you manifest your
    > ingenuity and trustworthiness

When articulating on the D-Day

-   Pay close attention to what you say

-   You are the only one who knows what is on the next-slide, next-para
    > and the next-minute

-   Expect the unexpected: Tech not working, Slides not showing up, Demo
    > fails, you fumble and all other possibilities

-   Only if you expect that an unexpected outcome will come your way,
    > you can respond with the presence of your mind

-   When responding to questions or unexpected timings, learn to pause.
    > Ask in your mind what you think about it. Listen and respond to
    > yourself first, quickly, and then tell the world

All this work will eventually shift your mind from being vague and
useless to dangerously articulate.

Imagine you are a military authority leading an army on a battlefield.
You are continuously explaining your situation to the superiors,
commanding the army, making life critical decisions and winning the war.
Post war, you are remembering, recognizing and recommending promotions.
All this needs great articulation skills so get ready to fire on all
cylinders

title: US Credit Downgrade Signals Fiscal Recklessness
content:
Did you ever get a lower than expected performance review or a poor
grade in your assessment? How did that happen and what were the impacts?
This has exactly happened similarly to the US credit rating recently.
Ray Dalio, a great economist of our times, beautifully explains
[[this]{.underline}](https://substack.com/@marketsentiment/note/c-119362970)
in 90 seconds and the write-up below drills a little more.

**Downgrade of US' Credit Sovereign Rating**: With Moody's downgrade of
credit sovereign rating from AAA to AA1, as of May 2025, the United
States no longer holds a top-tier sovereign credit rating. This happened
largely on three counts:

-   The U.S. national debt has reached approximately \$36 trillion and
    > is projected to increase further in the coming years. For
    > definition, this debt is the amount the US government owes from
    > borrowing to cover deficits. Debt is largely due to funds raised
    > from the public, foreign and institutional investors in the form
    > of Bonds. Bonds incur regular interest payments and return of the
    > principal at maturity

-   Secondly, as you continue to spend more than the revenue you
    > generate as a government, the deficits increase, raising concerns
    > about fiscal sustainability. Naturally, when you spend more than
    > how much you earn, it will have several implications

-   You may have heard about the 'One Big Beautiful Bill Act', which is
    > expected to be enacted by July 4, is currently under review of the
    > US senate, and will significantly change the fiscal game. Besides
    > changes in Energy, Technology and Healthcare policy changes, the
    > bill incorporates increased spending and reduced revenues for the
    > US government in the form of:

    -   Provisions for additional Income Tax cuts

    -   Increase the debt ceiling from \$36 Trillion by another \$4
        > Trillion

    -   Increased spend on Defense and Border Security by more than
        > \$200B

**Downstream impacts of the Downgrade**: Given the downgrade, this could
reduce the demand for these bonds. This will necessitate tjat government
to increase the yields (interest payments). When the yield on the bonds
increases, it will have two effects:

-   You are paying a higher interest payment for the bonds, so you will
    > pay more to service the debt. This explains the push to raise the
    > debt ceiling by \$4T

-   This will also push the central banks (Federal Reserve) to increase
    > or maintain the interest rate for general borrowings

Additional downstream impact, which is not significantly evident yet,
can happen on the following sectors:

-   **Equity Markets**: Corporate borrowing will be discouraged and risk
    > appetite to invest in equity markets can further dilute,
    > especially in the interest rate sensitive segments like
    > Real-Estate, Utilities and Growth Tech

-   **Currency**: This can weaken the exchange rate of the US dollar,
    > however there is also a counter that due to its nature as a
    > standard reserve currency of the US dollar, it might rise to
    > manage global risks. This can also lead to printing of more
    > dollars domestically to fulfill the demand side from the increased
    > supply of bonds

-   **Gold**: This may increase investor optimism for gold and other
    > hard assets, leading to an increase in price of these commodities

While the downgrades reflect concerns about the U.S. fiscal position, we
have seen limited immediate impact on financial markets. U.S. Treasury
securities continue to be viewed as safe assets due to the country\'s
strong economic fundamentals and the dollar\'s role as the global
reserve currency. The US' GDP is still \$10T+ greater than its next
rival in China.

The downgrades serve as a warning signal, highlighting the need for
policymakers to address the nation\'s fiscal challenges proactively.

So coming back to where we started, when you get a small ding in your
performance review or your grades in academia, just look at it as a
warning cycle and build a path to recovery. This points me to yet
another great remark by Adam Grant stating,

> **"The most underrated career skill is the ability to receive tough
> love. Acquiring knowledge is easy. Obtaining constructive criticism is
> hard. If you can\'t handle the truth, people stop telling you the
> truth.\
> The people who grow the most are the ones who take feedback the
> best."**

title: Technology Creates Paradox for Entry Talent
content:
Readers of this post are a combination of talented AI and technology
enthusiasts, Gen Z (Born in 1997--2012 phase), non-tech but \'curious
about technology\' business professionals and corporate employees.
Today's topic may relate to you directly or will certainly impact many
younger family members who are navigating academically or are in the
defining moments of their professional being. Let me start with an
oxymoronic state.

**Technological Oxymoron**: Over the last two decades, I have been a big
supporter and a sponsor of employing Early in Career Talent (EiCT). I
could work with my teams and organizations to create hundreds of starter
set jobs.

Over the years, a lot of experimentation, research and adoption of
technologies was enabled by Early in Career Talent (EiCT). First time in
the history of time, as we look at the generative nature of the AI
tools, these tools perform the exact tasks that college kids did right
out of college. As a result, these tools have created the largest \'net
negative\' impact on entry level white collar jobs, especially for those
with 1 to 5 years of experience.

This situation will need a very highly committed operating model that
will necessitate that corporates, governments, and academia define the
forward looking work model for the new generation --- otherwise the
doomsday will actually begin right after the college graduation
ceremony.

**Recent Commentary from Leaders**: Here are some relevant notable
remarks from many of the technology and political leaders.

-   President Barack Obama recently acknowledged the shorter work week,
    > necessity for Universal Basic Income (more like subsidies to me)
    > or need for building supplemental incomes. He also emphasized on
    > upskilling to exist in the automating world or prepare to be left
    > behind (Ref: Obama Foundation Democracy Forum)

-   Sam Altman by the virtue of AI Co-pilots mentions that an effective
    > software developer in 2025 is significantly different than what
    > she was in 2023

-   Dario Amodei, CEO of Anthropic, recently
    > [[commented]{.underline}](https://youtu.be/zju51INmW7U?si=srK_r9u5Cumtuydf)
    > that more than half of entry level jobs will disappear, leading to
    > 10 to 20% Unemployment --- further strengthening the challenge for
    > the Early in Career Talent (EiCT)

-   Satya Nadella, Microsoft CEO,
    > [[suggests]{.underline}](https://www.varnafarmerscoop.com/news/story/32425963/let-s-have-that-industrial-revolution-type-of-growth-microsoft-ceo-satya-nadella-wants-10-gdp-growth-from-ai)
    > that the level of impact that AI should aim for must lead to 10%
    > GDP growth. For me, getting to GDP growth at 10% along with AI
    > enabled unemployment sounds either oxymoronic or that the wealth
    > disparities will increase significantly necessitating governmental
    > interventions

-   Micha Kaufman, CEO of Fiverr, strongly mentions that from AI, easy
    > tasks will cease to exist for humans and hard tasks will become
    > easier. AI is coming to take everyone's jobs including his own

**What should I do?**

-   Firstly, if you look back in time, the ancestral work mode of 7 days
    > a week changed to 5 days a week. Some jobs barely need 40 hours a
    > week and will get to a 30 hour work week. I am not suggesting that
    > one works less now, however keeping everything at the same
    > baseline, if you smartly employ the right tools, your job can now
    > be done in 30 hours or even less

-   Anything that a remote worker does today will be simplified by AI.
    > Instead of looking at AI as a threat, divide your job in parts as
    > opposed to a complete job and determine which parts of your job
    > can leverage AI and automation tools

-   Look for additional functions/roles in adjacency that you can start
    > learning and supporting. As a recruiter, teacher, technologist,
    > marketeer, photographer, product manager, copywriter, sales
    > person, service engineer, designer, data scientist or whatever you
    > do today, you should be able to do this and the step above

-   Encourage and be encouraged to build affinity towards physical and
    > non-technology based industries

-   AI change cannot be disruptive overnight and it will be gradual. If
    > you look for it, you will have ample opportunities to intersperse
    > AI in your life

-   Complexity of human interactions, creative problem solving,
    > contextual understanding, need for comprehensive skills set,
    > regulatory expectations and physical dexterity still offer moat
    > for AI to intersperse easily

**World Economic Forum -- Future of Jobs
[[Report]{.underline}](https://reports.weforum.org/docs/WEF_Future_of_Jobs_Report_2025.pdf)
(2025)** nicely articulates the growing and declining jobs on page 21.
Use this as a reference to understand the future especially for those
navigating to become EiCT. Advise next gen to make sensible academic
investments.

Let's hope that AI regulation, Academic reforms, Guidance to the
Corporations in advanced economies is prioritized in addition to
becoming the AI masterchef --- else the domestic chaos will continue to
significantly impact unrest.

title: Automation Unmans Warfare and Physical Spaces
content:
**Unmanning in the Real World**

Following the lead on 'Generative' nature of Large Language Models
significantly impacting entry level jobs, here is yet another point of
view on what other functions are being disrupted and where this
disruption is happening.

**Technology leading to 'Unmanning' aspects**

Following are some example disruptions created by the AI-driven robotics
enablement in warfare and physical spaces:

-   'Renovate Robotics' is an AI-based Robotics Automation company that
    > automates roof installation as a co-contractor, promising to boost
    > productivity, ensure safety, speedy implementation and precise
    > installation of shingles on the roof

-   Another company, Covariant, has built a Robotics Foundation Model
    > (RFM) where robots are enabled with human-like reasoning ability.
    > RFM is trained with text, image and video data to create robotic
    > actions in the real-world to automate warehouse operations, for
    > example

-   Modern day defense technologies are leading to humanless warfare
    > where companies like Anduril & Shield.AI promise to protect
    > civilians and enable armed forces to carry out complex missions
    > using autonomous unmanned aerial vehicles

-   In another instance, a company named Teledyne Flir has built
    > military microdrones for defense and covert reconnaissance

**Unmanning of the Intellectual Workspace**

Beyond the entry level jobs and skilled workforce (military and factory
automation) is the impact on the intellectual workforce. This impact is
coming through the advent of AI agents. An AI agent leverages reasoning
ability, remembrance/memory and workflow automation tools to conduct
human-like business as an advanced employee would. The ability to
reason, plan and take action based on information it's given, this AI
agent simulating a digital employee thinks, remembers and gets things
done. There are three parts to this:

-   Presence of brain is demonstrated through the effective use of LLMs
    > which are used for reasoning, planning and language generation

-   Memory in the form of datasets and history of past interactions
    > allows tracking of continuity and successful results to take
    > future action

-   Finally, the AI agent will use tools like Email, Workflow Tools and
    > other new age technologies to interact with the outside world

A simple example is a Customer Service Agent. Compared to Generative
AI-based internship-like behaviours, an AI agent is trained with
customers, products, and several scenarios to support customers just
like a human-based agent would work with the customers. There is also
the ability to remember past interactions for reference and for training
as any human agent would have. At some point in the near future, I want
to create an example AI agent which I will look forward to sharing with
a real-life example.

**I don't have time to understand and use these AI Agents?** On average,
as a working professional we attend 15 meetings every week and
additionally spend 1/3rd of our time responding to emails or chat
messages. Also account for time spent on distractions and social media.
This busy bee mindset numbs us out and prevents us from finding real
freedom --- creating space to take a break, to think, and to innovate.
This perceived burnout leads to 4 million people quitting their rat-race
jobs every month in the United States.

The good thing is between Digitization, AI and pandemic, we have gotten
better. Our productivity has increased with many organizations moving
towards a 4-day work week, explicitly or implicitly. This has been
experimented with reduced time at work in Spain, Scotland, Norway,
Denmark, US, Ireland, France and Germany. Certain jobs that are low
paying in nature or certain cultures where a long working hours mindset
is a dominant aspect are finding it hard to change.

It is imperative that you figure out ways to make yourself more
efficient through effective meeting management, time management and
investment in using the new age tools.

title: Money Habits Reflect Culture Not Logic

relevance.Culture_Awareness: How organizational culture shapes behaviors and financial habits

content:
As a young person, are your parents critical about your excessive
spending habits? If you are a parent, do you feel that your children do
not understand the value of money? Are our spending and money management
habits a function of upbringing, culture around us, geography, parental
influences, next gen or just unique to us? Possibly, some combination of
these. However, in addition, our spending behaviours, wealth creation,
and money management are intrinsically determined by many factors
unknown to us. Here is a deep dive

**Savings, Consumption and Wealth creation abilities around the world:**

-   Here is a simple list representing average savings rate from earned
    > 100 currency units for various countries: \~5% for an American,
    > \~35% for a Chinese, \~18% for an Indian, 6% in the UK and 10-15%
    > in Japan & Germany

-   Consumption & Spendings by the individuals determine growth of GDP
    > (Gross Domestic Product) by definition. Higher the spend, higher
    > the GDP

-   China, structured as a communist nation, conspires via a state
    > directed capitalist economy. In a nutshell, Chinese government
    > determines year over year directional spends to determine sectors
    > for economic growth

-   Earlier mention of high savings rate in China reduces consumption
    > within the economy. This forces the government to make investments
    > in sectors like factories, infrastructure, automation (EVs) and
    > real estate to push for GDP growth

-   Top 4 Banks in the world are based in China and they hold \$20T+ in
    > assets more than what the country makes in a year. China's
    > property market is about \$130T in value

-   Comparatively, an average American saves only 5% for what she earns.
    > With less than 4% of the global population, Americans spend 1 out
    > of 3 dollars across the planet making it the largest consuming
    > economy.

**What encourages us to Spend & Consume vs. Save & Invest?**

-   China, for example, has bigger challenges from poverty, famines and
    > crisis management. Citizens don't trust the government and as a
    > result they are pushed to save

-   Owning real estate in some countries like India and China is a
    > status symbol. Owning a home can be a prerequisite to marriage

-   Social security (Post retirement care) in these countries is not
    > reliable and healthcare is not accessible with ease

-   China manufactures 20 billion pieces of clothing with 1.4 billion
    > people citizens, has housing to accommodate 3 billion citizens,
    > has over built road and rail network, manufactures 4.5 billion
    > appliances annually, produces 1.4 billion cell phones annually,
    > manufactures steel enough to fulfill half the world's demand,
    > produces EVs in large quantities and manufactures with an export
    > orientation. This as such does not help its citizens as such but
    > tries to drive growth with potential economic downturns

-   Comparatively, consumer confidence for larger nations in the Western
    > hemisphere is high. US leads the way in consumer spending, as
    > mentioned earlier

-   60% of Americans own stocks. The UK and Japan have 30%+ investors in
    > the stock market. Similarly, India is moving in this direction.
    > Investments in China are a bit more conservative focusing more on
    > real-estate and savings, away from its stock market

-   Countries printing of currency for citizens based consumption are
    > far more effective compared to countries like China that print
    > currencies to drive controlled/politicized economic growth

At large, spending habits of most Eastern hemisphere countries are
relatively conservative. Additionally, State run economies like China
reduce faith of the citizens in the nation's intent on individual level
wealth creation, forcing their citizens to save more. A lot of these
countries and economies acknowledge prosperity but do not make use of it
as they prosper.

**In Conclusion:** When citizens feel protected, educated, insured, and
with the convenience of infrastructure, they are encouraged to spend &
consume more. In another example, Berkshire Hathaway a U.S.-based
multinational conglomerate holding company led by Warren Buffett, holds
assets in excess of \$900B with only 5-7% of \$900B invested outside of
the US. They feel very confident about being protected with how the
country is governed at large.

As individuals, our consumption and spending at large is driven by
economic comfort and less by habits or culture. Incremental policy
reforms in growing economies lead to increased incomes and spending as a
result, which remain invisible to us in a way. Countries with
stagnated/rigid policy framework and corrupted state will have an impact
on both, the wellbeing of the citizens and the economic growth. These
nations will have to relinquish control to private companies and improve
their policy reforms significantly in order to prosper.

If you have incrementally grown your incomes, built the ability to
invest and feel more confident about the future then be assured that you
are in the right place. Be thankful!

title: Big City Life Is Daily Decathlon
content:
### **Equation of Adversaries:** In our life, we don't grow up with all the resources at our discretion 

### **Big City Decathlon** 

As a young person growing up in a big city like Mumbai, it felt like
living through a real-life, recurring Olympic decathlon --- except our
events were not on the track, but in the streets, staircases, and trains
of daily life. The disciplines? **Noise Pollution**, **Commuting by
Crowded Mumbai Local Trains**, **Space Management** (my 140 Sq Ft
Mansion --- yes, you read it right), **Social Inequality** (answering a
phone meant a five-storey climb and descent), **Identity Crisis** (Can I
bring friends over to my big fancy house?), and **Social (In)equality on
Display**, just to name a few.

Of course, those who came from small towns had their own decathlon ---
perhaps with issues of **infrastructure**, **power supply**, **access to
high-speed internet**, and other obstacles specific to their
environment.

### **So What? How Does This Matter?** 

Among other things, **your resiliency as a human is defined by your
upbringing**. Adversity forces you to play life's games like
*Tug-of-Work* and *Survival-of-the-Fittest*, sharpening your
**navigational abilities**. There are two parts to this:

1.  **Building upon who you are**

2.  **Defining your continuous being\
    > **

As the strength of a skyscraper lies in its foundation, **your ability
to withstand professional uncertainty and stand tall through
circumstantial storms** is a direct function of how your early
foundation was built.

Over time, you accumulate layers of experience --- learning to **deal
with failure**, to **stand out**, and most importantly, to **stand
tall**.

### **What's Your Modus Operandi? Invisibility, *In Visibility*, or *In Visibility for Your Convenience*** 

This is where you pause and reflect on **your own operating model**.

Just two hours ago, I completed a three-hour mandatory harassment
prevention course. As I reached step 99 out of 100, my browser crashed
--- everything reset. It felt like being bitten by the snake at square
93 in a childhood game of *Snakes & Ladders*. I will restart the
training.

But what does this have to do with your **modus operandi**?

### **There are these three Modes We Operate In** 

#### **ðŸ¥· 'Invisibility' Mode** 

In this mode, I become oblivious to my potential.\
\"I'm a doctor --- I have enough patients.\"\
\"I run an online market research firm --- I have paying customers.\"\
\"I have a job --- I meet expectations.\"

This gives me just enough growth to keep pace with inflation. I walk
with my head high, but I'm playing it safe.

#### **ðŸŽ­ 'In Visibility for My Convenience' Mode** 

I become **seasonally relevant**. I build marketing campaigns, push
throughput, launch a side project. This allows **non-standard growth**
--- maybe 2--3x inflation. I tap into my early-life Olympic resilience
but **only when I feel like it**. I use compounding, and it feels
good... but it's not my best game.

#### **ðŸ… Pureplay 'In Visibility' Mode** 

This is where the game changes. Your goal is no longer just money. You
push boundaries, step out of your comfort zone, and run a decathlon
every day.

Fans of *Better Call Saul* will remember when Saul Goodman offered 50%
discounts to drug offenders --- low margins, high volume. That's pure
hustle.

This is where:

-   You create **new solutions for new markets**

-   You test **unique ideas with confidants** before launching big

-   You operate in **full visibility**, not just for your personal
    > convenience

Like Rishabh Pant, who failed miserably in the IPL but scored
**back-to-back test centuries** --- it's not about the wins; it's about
the **attitude to go again**.

### **Go for the GOLD:** Your resilience and shaping didn't happen overnight --- they came from years of silent perseverance. 

Now ask yourself: "Am I truly playing in full visibility mode, or am I
just conveniently visible?" Search your soul.

title: Keep in Touch to Stay Relevant
content:
**You just need to Keep-in-Touch:** Although this write-up will sound
technical in nature, at the end of it, you will walk with solid
awareness and confidence to know how you as an individual and the ones
you care about new entrants in professional lives can successfully
practice AI.

**Retrospective State of Software Engineering**: There was a very very
high demand for software engineers and technology practitioners in the
early to mid-90s. I know of 100s of my colleagues who could advent into
the world of software without much of a formal education. They
successfully have made a mark in the software and the SaaS space today
leveraging some basic training and through experiential learning. This
era is repeating and worth exploring how.

A big difference between the 90s and today is in the fact that the
demand for software professionals was higher then than compared to the
ease with which software can be written now. Let's examine how.

**Software 1.0:** In this era, from client-server to very sophisticated
SaaS evolution, you wrote code in English like software languages to
instruct the computer(s) in the form of software programs. Easy enough.

**Software 2.0:** Imagine a Computer based AI chess player that is
playing a game against a grandmaster chess champion. Obviously, when the
computer is playing the game it is not programmed to remember all
possible combinations for moves of chess pieces. It uses a technique
called unsupervised learning where your computer is managed in the form
of a neural network. Neural network has something called weights which
are programmed to respond with chess moves. Evolution of self-driving
cars is based similarly where the neural capacity of a Full Self-Driving
mode uses the objects (other vehicles, traffic signals, people), the
road dividing lines and the lanes to create a neurological response to
drive the car.

**Software 3.0:** I believe Software 2.0 is a slightly complicated
representation that gets simplified here. Imagine that your computer is
now replaced by Large Language Models. You provide instructions in the
form of prompts to program and fine tune the model to get answers. This,
as you all have experienced by now, is in the form of English language
interactions.

As a new entrant in the AI space or as a graduating student, you need to
know how Software 1.0 existed and how you can fully exploit the power of
Software 3.0. Soham Parekh, a young and slightly misguided software
enthusiast, did exactly this without keeping focus on one-thing and got
distracted in the process.

Andrej Karpathy, ex-Director of AI and Auto Pilot vision at Tesla, has
beautifully explained these and some more AI concepts in this referenced
[[talk]{.underline}](https://youtu.be/LCEmiRjPEtQ?si=i3CUw5QA_mpMGlkX)
while addressing students who are at the verge of entering professional
life.

In his words LLMs/AI are like power that is needed for our existence.
This is a utility that needs a large Capital Expenditure investment
(build LLMs equivalent to building a power plant), its consumers needing
Operational Expenditure (Consume Power or Pay for tokens in the LLMs
context), need stability (power to be highly available), with no latency
(Light bulb glows as soon as turn the switch on), and with multiple LLMs
(Llama, OpenAI, Claude) just like getting power from your power grid,
battery, solar or oil based generators. In a nutshell LLMs are
equivalent to electricity.

**In conclusion:** With LLMs, everyone is a programmer, as most of us
speak English - a natural language. You don't need to study software
engineering to be able to program. He tweeted with a meme themed as
'Vibe Coding'. You blabber to the LLM, ignore long wielded assessment,
ignore a lot of meaning behind the code, keep talking the machine just
like a 5th grader till it produces code for your purpose. Virality of
the meme actually created a wikipedia entry on "Vibe Coding". Here are
the snapshots of his tweet and the Wiki page.

title: Corporate Buzzwords Are Toxic Bullshit

relevance.Communication: Recognizing and avoiding toxic communication patterns
relevance.Politics: Examples of toxic corporate language and culture

content:
You call your best friend for her advice on a situation. She tells you
to be *true to your inner self and follow your path*. **The Bullshit
served on a platter** --- and she lost a friend. This bullshit exists
everywhere, and this write-up will build a certain level of cognizance
and appetite to deal with it.

### **Toxic Culture that is Devoid of Meaning** 

Have you come across situations where leaders often say:

-   *"Let's circle back"* when they have no idea what to say at a given
    > point

-   *"We need to be agile"* so you can get \$#!+ done without asking for
    > guidance, budget, or more time

-   *"Think outside the box"* and tell me what I would like to hear

-   *"We need to empower our teams"* so that you are responsible for a
    > task without any authority on budgets or resources

-   *"We are on a transformation journey"* and I have no idea as a
    > leader what we will achieve --- however, we paid McKinsey a lot of
    > money to draw a pretty picture and a lot more

-   We are *"Data Driven"* or *"Customer Obsessed"\
    > *

Probably there are a dozen more examples --- and your favorites that you
can add to this list. Well, at first, believe me: you are not alone
looking to breathe in this kind of a world.

### **AI-led Human Hallucination** 

AI has given yet another flavor to this story. When we started the AI
journey, we quickly realized that early versions of LLMs hallucinated
**1 out of 6 times** --- saying things like *9.11 is actually greater
than 9.9*.

I have seen many podcasts and presentations where corporations are now
cluelessly aiming to be an *"AI First"* company. They speak about using
AI Agents, Co-Pilots, Model Context Protocols, and AI Applications ---
without having foundational AI strategies.

Compared to the Large Language Model hallucinating 1 out of 6 times,
**corporations are running like chicken without a head**. Leaders here
are hallucinating **perhaps more than 60% of the time** --- compared to
16% by the early LLMs.

### **So, Why does this happen?** 

Naturally, everyone wants to be relevant and be strategic in their
thought leadership. Nothing wrong with that.

This leads to **"Feel Good Fairy Dusting"** --- that complicates your
thought process **in** this abstracted world. These complicated words,
thoughts, and messages are far from reality.

They hear some bits in presentations, from service providers, peer
groups, and some events. They bring half-hearted guesswork into the
context of a professional setup.

### **How do you build cognizance, respond, and navigate in such situations?** 

-   Culture of the entity where you are an employee, participant,
    > contributor, or a creator matters a lot. Know the past history and
    > understand your ability to find the right people and ask good
    > questions. If the organization encourages a high-performing and
    > participative culture, then life will eventually balance out these
    > anomalies

-   After finding the right people, ask for relevant examples to the
    > first introduced fancy jargons in this write-up --- or for the
    > ambitious plans to navigate in the new-age AI-like transformation

-   If your environment and culture permit, bring courage in
    > perspective. Identify contradicting behaviors to what gets stated
    > in leadership messages and call out the underlying "BS" ---
    > obviously without explicitly using the BS word

-   This behavior trickles, and as a leader, you will start reflecting
    > it. Remove it from your mindset and from your language

-   Aim for **simplicity in your personal language** and ask your teams
    > and colleagues to aim for **clarity**. Stop creating and accepting
    > the fog of fancy words. Share knowledge with simple words and **do
    > not pretend** to become a social/professional media influencer

-   Most importantly, become a **student of life** and simply focus on
    > strengthening your **intellect\
    > **

In the last two decades, many organizations were born on the technology
cloud to build cloud-relevant solutions. These companies --- and
companies prior to them or newer non-technological organizations --- are
all trying to stay relevant in the new AI world.

If you are part of these organizations or an independent professional,
then build your own awareness through use of these tools. Recently, I
met many individuals who use the LLMs to do prep accounting work, legal
groundwork, or financial research. Their engagement with tax, legal, and
financial professionals **after** the use of these tools is simplified,
accelerated, and becomes cost-efficient. They leverage the power of
AI/LLMs for a lot of foundation work, remain savvy, and avoid becoming
**overly dependent** on specialist professionals.

Jargons and generalized inspiration are often used by leaders in their
conversation. As long as these thoughts are used as conversational
seasonings, things are okay. **But if they are part of your daily main
course or buffet, then it is time to look for a change.**

title: Inner Circles Breed Opinions Harm Organizations

relevance.Culture_Awareness: How inner circles damage organizational culture and trust
relevance.Politics: Political dynamics of inner circles in organizations

content:
### **Opinionated Inner Circles** 

In housing complexes, religious communities, large companies, families,
and groups of friends, there are inner circles --- and then there are
others. Inner circles are groups of people that find conformity and
comfort with each other. They think alike and rub their beliefs and
energies off one another. In the process, they build opinions about
those who are not part of the circle. A large, complex organization may
have many such inner circles.

Unfortunately, the broader organization sees these circles too --- and
develops opinions about them in return. When such groups become
entrenched over time, they often breed bitterness among people. Hatred
and lack of trust build over the years, and eventually, this impacts the
wellbeing of the entire setup. Major projects experience delays, red
tape, and disharmony from bureaucracies. Organizations suffer financial
losses.

At the same time, I've also seen that in times of crisis --- barring
extremist mindsets --- people pull together to face challenges. The
success of such organizations depends on leadership. Let me put a
situation in perspective.

### [**[You are (or can be) Contagious]{.underline}**](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cef35Fk7YD8) 

This excerpt is from a previous write-up and is relevant here.

When you meet a person for the first time, what do you look at? Face,
shoes, or body? Not quite --- they look at your hands first. Your hands
speak volumes: are you a hawk, a defender, or someone who welcomes?

Now I understand what it means to *welcome with open arms*. People look
at whether you are holding a rock, a scissor, or an offering of warmth.
If they can't see your hands, they can't see your intentions.

### **Celebrating Good Leaders** 

It's 5 pm on Friday. My team decides to go have a drink. On the way out
of the office, Amit Kumar --- one of my most celebrated leaders ---
takes 10 minutes to greet and wish a good weekend to every colleague he
passes, including the front desk and security staff.

Everyone waiting is irritated by this uncanny but predictable habit of
Amit. As irritating as it got for us, Amit is that *contagion* that
passes the positivity of life around. I've seen more leaders --- but he
always stood out.

Some good habits that he (and other good leaders) demonstrate:

-   They make people feel comfortable

-   They check on others: on their wellbeing

-   They decouple time-lapsed or recent biases and focus on the person
    > in front of them

-   They don't build toxins within --- and this could be a much longer
    > list

### **Wrong Leaders are Celebrated Often** 

As much as good leaders deserve to be celebrated, we too often see
**mediocre, incompetent, authoritative leaders** idolized. Why?

-   Sometimes they are celebrated due to **racism or sexism biases\
    > **

-   There is the **Action Fallacy** --- we mistake noise for leadership

-   They speak more, so we hear them more --- regardless of content

-   They demonstrate confidence, regardless of competence

-   They pretend to be perpetually busy, no matter the substance

-   They blow their own trumpets and love to recover from the mistakes
    > *they* caused

-   They are the self-proclaimed **captains of crisis\
    > **

The best way to discover good leaders is to introspect deeply on the
traits of both good and bad leadership. Look for leaders who:

-   Don't promote drama

-   Quietly accomplish big missions

-   Show empathy

-   And most importantly, **don't create inner circles\
    > **

### **Your Tenancy** 

Keeping myself in perspective, I can relate to many of the positive
traits above. I am rarely in an inner circle. I demonstrate empathy. I
avoid the action fallacy and resist creating drama.

In reality, your *tenancy* exists everywhere:

-   Inside the inner circles

-   As an observer of those circles you're not part of

-   As someone who appreciates your good traits

-   As someone who strives to avoid contributing to toxic culture

But the real question is:

> **Where do you pay the most rent?\
> ** In seeking attention --- or in driving results?\
> In action fallacy --- or in building a strong premise of integrity?

The best way to find out where you\'re living as a tenant?\
**Seek honest feedback from people you trust --- the ones who will help
you see the mirror.**

title: We're Addicted to Achievement Not Fulfillment

relevance.Goals: The difference between achievement addiction and true fulfillment

content:
**Chasing the Next Best Thing:** Our mind is always chasing - chasing to
be number #1 in school, getting to a top college, getting that job,
getting that promotion after the new job, building a successful business
or looking for the next best opportunity. Next holiday, a fancy car,
bigger home and the list goes on.

The race is always on and often supplemented by therapy,
antidepressants, displeasure and anger experienced by loved ones, and
sometimes futile efforts to calm yourself with meditation, no offense to
yoga teachers at home or otherwise.

We become addicts of achievement and constantly look for validation and
approval from others. Likes on Social Media, Appreciation from
Leadership, Praises from your workplace.

In search of this pursuit when people ask us how we are doing, the first
word that comes to mind is 'Busy'. At what cost? Invariably, our mental
and physical being are impacted. I have been a victim of this mode. So I
have come to terms with some of this and in all honesty, not entirely.

**Tug of War between Efforts and Outcomes:**

As humans we like to fit in, not create chaos, build tolerance as our
goal is to make notional achievements in kind (Promotion ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ’¼ðŸ“ˆâœ¨, Raise
ðŸ’¸ðŸ“ˆðŸ¤‘, New Job ðŸ’°ðŸ’ŽðŸš€, Social Status ðŸ‘‘ðŸ†). In the context of achieving
these notional achievements, we make a lot of upstream efforts where the
daily rut far exceeds your tolerance, necessitating a headache pill at
the end of each workday.

What if contrary to artificially fitting into achieving notional
achievements, we focus more on doing things that bring joy like playing
a sport, spending more time with friends, painting, cooking, fitness
regime or traveling. For me personally, I focus on intellectual
upliftment through my weekend research.

Once I/we do this, your psychological flow gets really smooth. When you
are working on a problem (work related or not), your mind will be
unburdened from the chaos that your expectations create. This
seamlessness will let you focus on the most productive ways of working.
Don't expect for what you do in your personal space to create magic in
your professional setup as there is more to do:

-   Don't be a Yes (wo)man to begin with

-   Identify the value that your presence brings to a task or a meeting

-   Escape from activities and conversations where you are not adding
    > value

-   Disconnect Actions from Expected Outcomes

-   Expect outcomes to be byproduct of your actions and not as
    > foundational goals

-   Avoid doing things that don't matter to your fabric and I am sure
    > there is more

If the expected activities compromise your fundamental beliefs then
choose a path to decouple from the situation (people, organizations or
initiatives)

**Expiry of Tolerance - Let's Move On:** In more than 3 decades of my
career, I have had a few bumpy days. A day when I walked into the office
unshaven from forgetting to shave, the time when my health parameters
took a detour... and ended up at a pizza parlour or when I realized
cultural toxicity. In all instances, I walked out, including relocating
to a new geography.

While you cannot quit or walk out unreasonably, make conscious choices
of how you operate on an everyday basis. It is hard to stay away from
attention addiction so keep assessing to decouple consciously from being
in that mode.
