title: Multitasking Creates Slippery Slopes Everywhere
content:
In my distant past, I had a colleague (Let's call him Sam) who was
working as a consultant at one of the client locations. This (over)smart
young man was working for two clients simultaneously. No big deal with
that however this is what happened. He used to claim for his hotel
accommodation from both the employers and once from sending his invoice
of client B to my food chain, he was caught. Embarrassed.

**Multi-tasking, Multi-skilling and Parallelization**

When you multi-task to your implied oversmartness or from aiming to be
very productive, you will encounter slippery slopes. It happens to all
of us with small things and big things. I had a messy kitchen this
weekend as hot tea spilled out from over boiling, owing to a small
distraction from another task. Multiple lessons to learn: switch over to
coffee, get my house in order before she gets here and realize that
ordinary humans can only perform one task at a time. Sometimes these
multi-tasking desires can lead to Sam-like embarrassments, let alone the
lack of integrity.

Multi-skilling is entirely and at the other end of the spectrum compared
to multi-tasking. Here you work to prevent obsolescence, simply speaking
to become resilient in this ever changing world and especially with
potential disruptions to be seen in the not so distant future. Here you
can build or develop brand new skills. As a business person you become a
real estate analyst/investor to diversify your portfolio. As a working
professional you become a fitness trainer. As a Marketing Analyst you
become a Public Speaker. As a Software Engineer you become a Solutions
Architect. As a Quality Assurance Engineer you become a Business
Analyst. As an Employee of an Organization you start a side gig. As a
commuter you become a part-time Uber driver. There are so many
possibilities.

A quick intro to Parallelization. The term 'Parallelization' is largely
referred to in computing architecture. CPU uses multiple threads to
execute different parts of a program simultaneously. Each thread handles
separate tasks improving overall productivity. Does this sound
Oxymoronic compared to the Multi-tasking narrative. Not quite. This is
about handling. As a leader sometimes you manage multiple functions, as
a home maker you have several home units to manage and as a
multi-skilled talented individual you have the ability to work on
several skills. A key differentiator between multi-tasking and
parallelization is between how you divide your time in chunks and how
you stop doing one thing before you start a new thing, with a seamless
hand-off.

**Importance of Multi-skilling and Parallelization:**

Many facets of Multi-Skilling

-   Given how easy it is to start a new side gig in the AI-age, everyone
    > must be encouraged to leverage the tools, learn new skills and
    > make hay while the sun shines

-   This will also allow you to defend obsolescence of a skill set. It
    > is projected that 80% of jobs will be automated for 80% of the
    > tasks in the near future. This will make our multi-skilled mindset
    > an imperative

-   Multi-skilling will help to easily Transition to a new phase of
    > life: as a mother, as a retiree, as a student, as a curious
    > person, as someone seeking a promotion, as to increase your value
    > through additional offerings in your workplace, as being relevant
    > with the new generation, as an aim to build/support your purpose,
    > and to create a brand new thinking perspective

Parallelization Playbook

-   You will build economies of scale from guiding/directing multiple
    > teams. This needs, as mentioned earlier, trust in people who do
    > the work for you and the guidance you provide to them with a very
    > effective hand-off

-   Have a fool-proof mechanism to ensure that the task you initiate
    > with a (wo)man or machine is performed with a high degree of
    > confidence

-   Ensure that you are not parallelizing unattended high risk
    > activities

**How to become an effective Multi-Skilled Parallelizer?**

This to me is more an art than a science.

-   Malcolm Gladwell's book Outlier introduced the mindset to spend
    > 10,000 hours to master a skill. At the same time, to learn a skill
    > you don't need to master it. [[Sometimes a skill can be learnt in
    > just 20
    > hours.]{.underline}](https://youtu.be/5MgBikgcWnY?si=y4sIWlHAvObNHgZC)

-   We impose a mindset on our loved ones, especially the children.
    > Sometimes we even conspire with them to be like us. Instead use
    > the imposition and conspiracy on self to reinvent yourself with
    > new skills

-   Become a vibe coder to write your software or a vibe prompter to
    > solve many problems with AI

Have you built new skills recently? Have you used your vibes to tinker
with AI tools? Are you aspiring to build new skills? Let me know.

title: Anyone Can Become AI Architect Today
content:
# **Characterizing an AI Architect** 

Oh no, AI again --- don't be scared. As technical as it sounds, anyone
reading this write-up can aspire to be an AI Architect. Read on. I've
tried to capture the themes that define an AI Architect or help you
build your AI Architecture. Five characteristics, followed by a
concluding question:

### **1. 'AI-Driven' Brand Ambassadors** 

An AI Architect is today's equivalent of a Webmaster.

A webmaster --- now a forgotten term in the AI age --- was once
responsible for creating and maintaining a company's internet
storefront. She ensured performance, content, functionality, and
security to manage an organization's online presence.

Similarly, an AI Architect represents customer-facing AI functions for
both internal and external consumers. As we progress, websites will
increasingly be replaced by AI Agents. Imagine a branded AI Agent for
customer support instead of a "Support" section on a website. The AI
Architect builds, coaches, and continuously improves these agents.

### **2. 'Open to All' Opportunity** 

AI Architecture is more than technical plumbing. It includes a secured
AI-enabled front end, design, aesthetics, values, tone of brand, and ---
importantly --- the ability to drive business outcomes. Given the
engineer-like and human-like qualities of today's AI stack,
professionals in User or Customer Experience roles can easily wear this
hat.

### **3. Thought Leaders** 

In 2022--23, when Large Language Models first emerged, we did not know
of AI Agents or Model Context Protocols. Model accuracy, capabilities,
and modalities are improving rapidly, and an AI Architect must
understand where AI is headed, not just where it stands today.

They analyze problems across time: how they would have been solved six
months ago, how they are solved today, and how they could be solved in
the future. For instance, we started with text-only inputs and outputs.
Today we have text, images, audio, and video. Tomorrow, we will have
robotics, AI glasses, and ambient inputs and outputs.

An AI Architect avoids repeating mistakes of the past. Many
organizations failed in cloud transitions by simply porting on-premise
systems "as-is." Similarly, customer service teams will evolve from
directly and conventionally engaging with customers to instead coaching
and refining AI agents --- embedding empathy, judgment, and resolution
into them.

### **4. Scrappy & Myopic** 

AI Architects don't let "perfect" be the enemy of "good." They live
iteratively, tolerate risk, and design strategies to improve
predictability while reducing model hallucinations. This requires
building a robust data strategy so that models can be trained on
organizational knowledge and applied to specific functions.

Their action orientation means not spending six months drafting an AI
strategy and another six months implementing it. Instead, they focus
myopically on solving real customer and business problems with simple,
usable AI Agents --- and then refining them using first principles.

### **5. AI Agents --- Buy or Build?** 

Should you buy or build your AI Agents?

-   **Buy**: Customer support leaders often prefer ready-to-use
    > frameworks from companies like Yellow.ai, Five9, Sierra,
    > Forethought, IBM WatsonX, or Zendesk AI.

-   **Build**: Engineering teams are naturally inclined to design their
    > own. A homegrown Customer Support Agent requires choosing the
    > right language model(s), embeddings, vector database, and
    > integrations with telephony, CRM, knowledge repositories, and
    > more. It involves planning for testing, upgrades, and model
    > migrations.

-   **Middle Path**: Platforms with no-code frameworks let you build AI
    > Agents with a full development lifecycle. They provide tools for
    > testing, feedback, and improvements, including scenarios where the
    > agent escalates to a human before going live.

### **Art or Science?** 

So, is AI Architecture an art or a science? Honestly, it has become a
**commoditized artistic platform built on the fundamentals of science.**

Do you agree?

*Thoughts inspired by:* [[YouTube

content:
### **Turning Butterflies into the Butterfly Effect** 

When I started writing about this topic over the weekend, I did not
expect that today would bring me a fresh story to share. Before I get to
that, let me go back to my early leadership years. I vividly remember
presenting a mock topic at a leadership development public speaking
training. I had chosen the wrong topic, froze midway, and embarrassed
myself.

Fast forward to now, decades later, with training through experience and
bumpy rides, I found myself presenting our strategy at a townhall
meeting. This was my first time addressing such a large gathering in my
new role. I had spent 15 hours preparing for a 15-minute talk. Just
before I could get to the virtual podium, I was told my time was cut
short to 7 minutes.

Did I freeze? Did I have butterflies in my stomach? Neither.

And it wasn't just the years of experience that made the difference. It
was a combination of several things:

-   **Preparation matters.** I stared at the content for hours. Even 30
    > minutes before the session, I hadn't fully finalized my
    > pitch---not because I wasn't confident, but because I kept
    > refining the message.

-   **Adversity strengthens character.** Instead of worrying about my
    > time being halved, I trained my mind to view these moments as
    > steps toward success.

-   **Expect the unexpected.** My years of working with Private Equity
    > firms were the best training. They set the bar high---not only for
    > returns but for people. Every presentation taught me one
    > certainty: always expect the unexpected.

-   **Connection over content.** What ultimately matters most is how you
    > connect with your audience---what's in it for them.

And here's a thought I keep repeating: kids today use AI as an assistant
in their studies. Teachers, knowing this, now expect 8th graders to
perform at graduate level. If that's what we expect of the next
generation, why should we expect less of ourselves? Leverage tools---AI
included---to shape your narratives. Doing so makes it much easier to
respond to the unexpected.

**Key takeaways:**

-   Build an appetite to step out of your comfort zone---often.

-   Make yourself visible, no matter how visible you already are.

-   Look for moments and opportunities---they don't always knock on your
    > door.

-   Practice, practice, practice---don't let fear fuel self-doubt.

-   Be bold enough to strike conversations with anyone.

-   Turn your butterflies into the **butterfly effect.\
    > **

In chaos theory, the butterfly effect suggests that a butterfly flapping
its wings in one part of the world could contribute to a tornado or
storm in another. Tiny actions, seemingly insignificant, can create
large and unpredictable outcomes.

So, the next time you feel butterflies in your stomach, remember: they
could be the very wings that set a storm of success in motion.

title: Being Pessimist Has More Upside Actually

relevance.Self_Awareness: The strategic value of pessimistic thinking and managing expectations

content:
The Subtle Art of Getting Things Done

I've been dissecting a short podcast and, believe me, the podcast is far more entertaining in value than what you will learn from this Sunday capsule. Still, with the occasional miss, my job is to writeâ€”so I am writing, irrespective. Here are some lessons of life.

Optimist or Pessimist?

There is no upside to optimism; one should rather be a pessimist. Over the years, we've been conditioned to always be hopeful. This time, let's weigh the value of being a pessimist.

Imagine giving your manager or client a deadline to deliver a proposal by Friday close of business. Instead, you submit it Thursday eveningâ€”complete, polished, and with tips they didn't expect. You not only beat the deadline but also add unexpected value. That's the power of underpromising and overdelivering.

Never Let Them Know What They're Working Toward

Think of a pawn in chess: the smallest, most ordinary piece. Its only instruction is to move one square forward. Nothing glamorous, nothing heroic. The pawn doesn't know that by simply following this humble rule, one step at a time, it may reach the other side of the board and transform into a queen.

Similarly, when you read one book a month or write one page a day, you build compounding habits that one day transform you into a critical thinker capable of solving life's hardest problems.

Punctuality

Many workplaces accept meetings starting 5â€“10 minutes late. But if six people sit waiting for two stragglers, that's an hour of collective time wasted.

Punctuality follows a simple rule: being early is on time, being on time is late, and being late makes you the punchline.

Don't Work Your Way Up the Ladder

Incrementalism rarely gets you to the top. Disruption does. True breakthroughs come from challenging norms, not following them. Airbnb redefined hospitality, Uber redefined transportation, and Full Self Driving is redefining mobility. Astonishing results demand disruptive thinking, not small steps up the ladder.

Let It Be Their Decision

Henry Ford famously said, "You can have a car of any color, as long as it's black." Contrast that with today, where customers demand customization, choices, and delightful surprises. Apple didn't just give people what they asked forâ€”they designed products that became indispensable.

Jony Ive and Sam Altman are now collaborating to design AI-native hardware. Their genius will be in letting people perceive the product as their own desired choice.

Standout and Don't Stand Out

If you're at the edge of a group photo, you might look widerâ€”or worse, be cropped out. The trick is finding the right place, the right people, and the right opportunities to achieve scale.

Out-Juvenile a Screaming Body

Bullies don't disappear after school; they reappear in workplaces, bringing toxicity. Don't let them win. Build a Fort Knox of capabilities and confidence. Use your voice. Stand your ground.

Assimilate First, Then Shine

When you enter a new workplace or culture, understand its conventions. Learn the idioms: "all bases loaded" in the U.S., "sticky wicket" in India, "red card" in Europe. Blend in first.

Once you've marked your presence and built your brand, reveal your authentic self. Authenticity, more than anything else, will carry you forward.

This piece took me a while to write, especially as I translated Barry Sonnenfeld's PodFuncast into this capsule. But the lessons are worth the effort.

content:
Bullying and Condescension

While writing this week, I looked up the origin of the word bully, assuming it had something to do with being "bull-like." Actually, not quite.

Bully originated in the 16th century from the Dutch word boel, meaning affectionate lover, brother, or sweetheart. Over the years, it shifted into describing someone who pushed love and affection too forcefully. Today, of course, a bully is understood as someone who habitually mistreats those perceived as weaker.

Condescensionâ€”or condescending behaviorâ€”is about belittling others. In both bullying and condescension, the weaker ones are diminished.

In childhood, overt bullying often manifests as physical or verbal abuse. Covert bullying is subtlerâ€”exclusion from games or social groups. Condescension, meanwhile, shows up as superiority through wealth, skills, or status. Both mistreat those considered weaker.

In Organizations

In established organizations, bullies rarely show up with physical aggression; that would get them out the door quickly. Instead, they adopt condescending behaviors. We'll use the terms interchangeably here. Why do they condescend?

-   A newcomer trying to fit in may overemphasize how things were done in a prior job.

-   Some leverage implicit expectations from the food chain, acting as though they know the "secret sauce" of what management or customers want.

-   Patronizing tones instill fear, often covering up their own insecurities.

-   Their social life outside work is constrained; they may themselves be bullied at home by a dominating partner.

-   They feel unappreciated or unrecognized.

-   They seek to protect underperforming peers from being exposed by your competence.

And surely, there are more reasons.

How Do You Deal With Them?

The Being/Doing Part

-   Show up every day to give your best to your assignment.

-   Connect your contributions to the mission and purpose of the larger organization.

-   Ensure your work and value creation are impeccable.

-   Build relationships with colleagues who can foster your intellectual development.

-   Avoid watercooler conversations.

-   Create a strong narrative of your contributions and share your impact periodicallyâ€”without overplaying your trumpet.

The Mental Being

-   If their behavior keeps you restless or sleepless despite your strong performance, then you're part of the problem too.

-   Recognize that they have minimal control over your assignments, career, or rewards.

-   Focus on continuously raising your bar on the being/doing side.

-   Build a plan with a longer horizon than this individual's potential success.

-   Don't be distracted by the fact that some thrive by "sweet talk." Like excessive sugar in the system, it eventually takes its toll.

The Giving Back Part

-   If your workplace fosters open-door culture, knock and have an honest conversation.

-   Acknowledge strengths where you see them; if you can't find any, don't overengineer praise.

-   Tell the person directly how their behavior affects you and its impact on your work and mental well-being.

-   Be direct and objectiveâ€”this isn't the place for subtlety.

-   Document instances. At some point, you may need factual records.

I've also seen younger professionals take a more intolerant stand: they demonstrate courage to have direct conversations and, importantly, the courage to walk out of toxic workplaces.

A Final Reflection

How do you want to be remembered? While processing this, don't assume you yourself are never a bully. It's possibleâ€”unknowinglyâ€”you may be one. Seek continuous feedback and self-assess.

Imagine a disgruntled co-worker who leaves a job and tells her new colleagues in the break room:

  "When this great ex-manager who isn't around anymore looks down at meâ€¦"
  (a sarcastic sob and pause) "â€¦Not from the heavens. He was just condescending."

That's the thingâ€”condescension makes others feel like living ghosts hovering beneath you. The idea is not to become the villain in someone else's horror story.

Before I start with the thoughts, my apology for missing out for a
couple of weeks. At some point, I will write about what transpired. For
now, yet another tale of two cities. This time, I will only write about
one of the two cities. I will follow up shortly to write about the
second one and get into how individuals and economies can plan and
respond to these stimuli.

Here we go with definitions first. It does not harm even if they repeat.
If you are familiar with these definitions, then you can skip to the
main update following the five definitions below.

**CPU (Central Processing Unit):** Remember the big desktop machines
that had largely three parts --- a display screen, keyboard/mouse, and a
big box that we used to call a CPU. I am not referring to the big box,
but to the main chip inside those big boxes and now in your laptops and
smartphones. A CPU is a general-purpose processor that executes computer
instructions, manages logic, control, and computation across diverse
applications efficiently.

**GPU (Graphics Processing Unit):** In 2012--13, when I was working for
MSC Software, we had access to a GPU card from NVIDIA when we had no
idea that this provider would become the world's most valued company in
2025. The same GPU --- with many advanced versions from that point on
--- is now used to accelerate large-scale mathematical computations in
AI, namely the build-out of Large Language Models.

**DPU (Data Processing Unit):** NVIDIA also now builds and sells DPUs,
which offload data movement, encryption, and virtualization tasks from
CPUs for efficient cloud workloads. As such, both GPUs and DPUs work as
co-processors or copilots to the CPUs.

**TPU (Tensor Processing Unit):** Google built this AI-specific
processor to accelerate deep-learning matrix operations, optimizing
performance for neural network training and inference.

**QPU (Quantum Processing Unit):** QPUs will be used to perform
massively parallel probabilistic computations beyond classical limits.
For now, just appreciate the reference to "probabilistic" and "quantum"
contexts as these will be closely tied to the principles of quantum
mechanics as leveraged in quantum computations.

The reason for mentioning these five processors is to appreciate that
NVIDIA will play in the space of GPUs, DPUs, and QPUs in the long run.
Google will continue evolving the TPU space. And the fact remains that
CPUs have existed historically for a very, very long time --- ever since
the introduction of computers to mankind.

title: Telescope Thinking vs Microscope Execution
content:
# **Telescope or Microscope** 

Every so often, you meet someone who proudly proclaims, "I don't get
paid to do that." This thinking is the opposite of what fuels great
careers, great teams, and great organizations. So let's borrow two
magnificent tools from science to rewire how we look at work.

On one side: the James Webb Space Telescope, scanning galaxies 13
billion years away and expanding our sense of what's possible. On the
other: nanotechnology, operating at the scale of molecules, proving that
the smallest moves can transform entire industries. One widens
imagination; the other sharpens precision. In today's world---be it
corporate, entrepreneurial, artistic, medical, or professional---we need
both.

But mindset transformation begins with choosing the telescope first.

## **1. The Telescoping View: Seeing Beyond the Ordinary** 

Zoom out far enough, and your job description becomes a
footnote---useful, but hardly the full story. A telescopic mindset helps
you recognize how your role connects across the constellation of people:
customers, colleagues, partners, society, and the future you are
shaping.

With that view, even everyday tasks become mission-linked.

-   A developer isn't checking in code; they're contributing to
    > reliability that drives revenue.

-   A cashier isn't just scanning items; they're shaping a moment that
    > defines whether a customer returns

-   A physician isn't simply diagnosing; they're restoring someone's
    > ability to return to life, family, and purpose

Through the telescope, lines in a job description blur, and horizons of
impact sharpen.

## **2. Doing More Than What's Asked --- For the Right Intent** 

Doing more is not about burnout, martyrdom, or being the "office hero."
It's about thoughtful contributions rooted in the bigger mission. When
you act with telescopic awareness, your bar rises naturally.

-   You preempt risks instead of reacting.

-   You improve inefficient processes because they slow down everyone,
    > not because someone told you to.

-   You step into gaps because you care about outcomes, not because your
    > title authorizes it.

This isn't overwork. It's ownership.

People who think this way grow faster, lead earlier, and build
reputational equity that outlasts any role. They aren't valuable because
they do more---they're valuable because they see more.

## **3. The Five Lenses: The CORE+ Framework** 

To simplify the five behaviors into something memorable, here's a
five-letter acronym: CORE+.

Each letter captures a mindset that transcends titles, industries,
seniority, and professions.

**C --- Customer-Cognitive Mindset\
** Think like the customer you are serving. Anticipate their needs,
interpret what they truly want, and design your actions around their
experience. The best professionals read the room, the data, and the
unstated expectations.

**O --- Ownership for Value & Growth\
** Everything you touch should improve something: revenue, trust,
efficiency, safety, reliability, or skill. People with an ownership
mindset don't wait to be assigned value---they create it.

**R --- Results Through Product Thinking\
** Whatever you produce---a report, a legal brief, a diagnosis, a
marketing plan, a service interaction---is a "product" of your thinking.
Treat it like an artifact the world will use and judge. Quality becomes
your signature.

**E --- Excellence in Service Orientation\
** Service is not subservience. It's clarity about why your role exists:
to enable someone else's outcome. Leaders, creators, analysts,
physicians, engineers---all serve someone. When service becomes a
mindset, not a function, your influence multiplies.

**+ --- Culture Creation\
** The plus sign symbolizes your force multiplier. Culture is shaped by
micro-behaviors: how you respond under stress, how you treat colleagues,
how you share credit, how you listen, and how you show up. People who
elevate culture uplift entire systems.

Together, CORE+ forms the foundation of working beyond the narrow
boundaries of "what's written in my job description."

## **4. Redefining Monday --- and the New Year Ahead** 

Here's the truth: the gap between average and exceptional is measured in
tiny adjustments, not massive reinventions. Your next Monday starts with
a telescopic question:

**"What's the bigger mission my role contributes to?"**

Then a microscopic one:

**"What single action today can elevate value, culture, or customer
experience?"**

Your new Monday might involve:

-   closing one cross-functional gap that no one owns,

-   improving one broken process,

-   helping one colleague without prompting,

-   listening to one customer more deeply,

-   driving one behavior that strengthens CORE+.

Live this every week, and your new year resolution becomes
self-fulfilling:\
**Expand your field of vision, shrink your excuses.**

My next piece will focus on the art of acting without explicit
instructions---building a super-cognitive awareness of the world around
you. Today was the telescope; next time, we will pick up the microscope.

title: Benchmark Discomfort Not Comfort Friends

relevance.Goals: Benchmarking against excellence, not mediocrity or comfort

content:
**Benchmarking for the Art of (Im)possible**

We have heard that we are the average of the five people closest to us.
Though it sounds relatively simple and comforting, it is dangerously
incomplete. More on why?

We have strange habits when it comes to benchmarks. We benchmark by
wealth, wisdom, character and most importantly by accomplishments. The
implicit mind also keeps underperformers close, not out of compassion,
but convenience. We can tell them, advise them and flaunt our being in
front of them. They act as our emotional mirrors, reassuring us that we
are doing fine and better than them. It is like buying dopamine for free
leading to temporary happiness and zero growth. This sometimes gets into
lazy benchmarking. Also, your mind does not know that this is happening.
We confuse comfort with progress. And then, we wonder why years pass
without significant progress.

High achievers, in contradiction, work differently. They benchmark
against people who make them uncomfortable. They study those who prepare
more obsessively, persevere longer when motivation fades, and practice
even when no one is watching. They pay attention not just to what is
delivered, but how it is wrapped---the storytelling, the packaging, the
ability to move ideas from raw intelligence to compelling narratives.

This is where the shift happens---from the art of the possible to the
art of the impossible. This shift begins with choosing better
benchmarks.

Let me share a real example. It\'s 2:00 a.m. in India. Middle of the
week. The night of his birthday. Tarun just turned 25. His evening
moving into late night would have been like loud music, drinks galore,
and tomorrow written off in advance.

At 2 a.m., Tarun is not sloshed. He was inquisitive. He was asking
questions that most people don\'t ask until their late thirties---if
ever. I was in New York and he along with his teammate found me since it
was a convenient time for me to be available. He spent the hour with me
speaking about preparation, perseverance, and practice---not as
motivational words, but as systems. He was dissecting how high
performers think, how they tell their stories, how they raise standards
quietly and relentlessly. On his birthday. That is not a
coincidence---that is benchmarking.

Tarun isn\'t measuring himself against the average 25-year-old. He\'s
benchmarking against a future version of excellence---and working
backwards.

Are your benchmarks making you comfortable---or making you better?

**The 4Ps: A Framework for Upward Benchmarking**

High achievers, consciously or otherwise, benchmark across four
dimensions. Let\'s call them the 4Ps.

**1. Preparation:** Preparation is invisible work---you show up early,
leave late, and compound quietly. People who benchmark upward obsess
over inputs, not outcomes. They simulate scenarios before they occur. My
favorite with that is from the years of learning from Dominic Gallello,
my favorite leader. You walk into his meetings expecting the unexpected.

Average performers prepare just enough to survive. High performers
prepare enough to expect the unexpected.

**2. Perseverance:** Perseverance is misunderstood as grit. It\'s not.
Rather, the benchmark shifts from \"Can I do this?\" to \"Can I stay
with this longer than others?\"

**3. Packaging (The Forgotten Multiplier):** Ideas don\'t travel unless
they\'re packaged. Storytelling is not fluff---it\'s leverage. The best
performers study how ideas are framed, not just formed. They watch how
leaders simplify complexity, how narratives are built, how timing and
tone matter.

**4. Possibility â†’ Impossibility:** This is the final leap. Most
benchmarks live in the realm of the possible: realistic goals,
incremental growth, sensible ambition. Necessary---but insufficient.

The great benchmarks operate in the realm of the impossible, the 10x
thinking and the force multiplier.

This trait alone separates followers from hallmarks. Do you have
implicit bias for comforting benchmarks? Have you thought of your 10x
goals? Do your biases prevent you from 10x expectations?

title: Compete With Standards Not People

relevance.Goals: Competing with standards and personal growth, not with people

content:
**Is your life a Nextflix Revenge Series?**

**No Enemies, Only Elevation:** Most always our implicit thinking is
about how we are seen and how we want to respond to get back at
something. We think with the 'tit for tat' mind, a scorekeeping behavior
or retaliatory reciprocation. Someone ignores you, you ignore them back.
Someone blocks you, you return the favor---emotionally, socially,
professionally. It feels fair and balanced, however it is deeply
unproductive.

Your competition is not with people, but standards. Standards of
thinking, standards of behavior, standards of growth - the standards you
set for yourself. Families, friendships, teams, and organizations are
not battlegrounds; they are arenas where we either elevate each other or
slowly decay through scorekeeping.

At work, tit-for-tat shows up quietly. A colleague doesn't credit you in
a meeting, so you withhold information next time. A manager challenges
your idea publicly, so you disengage privately. The relationship becomes
transactional, brittle, and small. The irony? The real
competition---market forces, smarter startups, faster
technologies---don't care about your internal cold war.

At home and socially, the pattern repeats. "I called last time." "They
didn't show up for me." Relationships turn into spreadsheets. But human
bonds don't compound through arithmetic; they compound through
generosity and context. Often, people are not against you---they are
simply dealing with something you cannot see.

**Wearing the other Person's Shoes:** Which brings us to a critical
muscle most of us undertrain: *seeing what you don't see*. Our cognitive
biases love stories about heroes, villains, success, failures, and
glamour. Reality is messier. We tend to operate with partial
information, hidden pressures, and expectations for outcomes, eventually
to realize we did not get what we expected in the first place. Expecting
the unexpected isn't pessimism; it's maturity. When you pause and ask,
"What might I be missing?" you dissolve conflicts before they harden.

This matters even more today because many of our "rooms" are invisible.
They are not conference rooms but video tiles, delayed replies, or just
a voice on a call across time zones. Tone collapses in emails. We often
misread responses or lack thereof as resistance.

Watercooler conversations are even more dangerous. Hearsay from a third
person---often incomplete---cements opinions before direct engagement.
Reading an invisible room requires slowing down, listening for what
isn't said, and checking assumptions early---before imaginary enemies
form.

This needs a fix of proximity---to influential people. Not influential
by title alone, but by gravity. People who raise the quality of
conversation, think in systems, and stay calm under pressure. You find
them by observing who others turn to when things go wrong. You approach
them not with asks, but with curiosity.

**So how do we start afresh in 2026?** Rewire your minds with a
long-game logic. Set a very high bar and standards, somewhat
hyperbolically impossible to achieve. Work hard to live up to your high
bar expectations Assume positive intent until proven otherwise---and
even then, respond with clarity, not retaliation. Widen your lens. Be
deliberate about the rooms you enter, visible or invisible. Choose
circles that stretch you.

Once you can commit to wire your mind to this thinking, you can set
functional or performance goals.
